Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Implicit Modeling of Nonpolar Solvation: Towards Reliable Atomistic Simulation of Intrinsically Disordered Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate atomistic simulation of large conformational changes of proteins remains one of the greatest challenges in computational biology. Implicit treatment of the solvent environment has recently emerged as the premier alternative to traditional explicit solvent with a desired balance between accuracy and speed. The objective of this CAREER project is to develop, optimize and assess novel implicit treatments of nonpolar solvation to better balance competing electrostatic and nonpolar interactions. The second objective is to combine simulation and experiment to understand the structure, interaction and control of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs). IDPs are an important newly recognized class of functional proteins that rely on a lack of stable structures for function. The heterogeneous and dynamic nature of IDPs presents significant challenges for detailed characterization with either experiment or simulation alone. The PI will combine implicit solvent modeling, advanced sampling techniques, and NMR experiment to address these challenges. A novel hypothesis to be tested is that long- range electrostatic interactions can act concertedly with fly-casting to facilitate efficient recognition of IDPs. New and fundamental information will be obtained on the molecular principles of IDP structure and interaction. A practical outcome of this project will be an improved implicit solvent protein force field that can be broadly applied to study protein structure, dynamics and interaction.

The new protein modeling tools will be directly incorporated into training and educational activities including practical course units, training projects involving undergraduate and high school students, and summer workshops for a diverse selection of participants. Specifically, the PI will: 1) develop and revamp undergraduate and graduate courses to increase interdisciplinary awareness at an early stage of education and to provide basic training in biomolecular simulation that is much needed at Kansas State University (KSU); 2) continue to actively contribute to outreach programs at KSU including Women in Engineering and Science Program, Developing Scholar Program and Bridges to the Baccalaureate to increase the participation of women and other minorities in science; 3) initiate annual two-day summer workshops to enhance the knowledge of computational and structural biology for college and high school teachers. Special emphasis will be placed on recruiting teachers from community colleges in southern Kansas that have a large Hispanic student population and traditionally show weakness in student preparation. These workshops will help foster new collaborations in research and education with minority-severing institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) are a newly recognized class of functional proteins that rely on a lack of stable three-dimensional structure for function. They are key components of regulatory networks that dictate many aspects of cellular decision-making, and are enriched in major disease pathways. There is an urgent need to establish the fundamental principles of how intrinsic disorder mediates protein function and how such functional mechanisms may be altered in human diseases. This NSF-supported project has helped to address this critical need by: 1) successful development of several advanced computer simulation approaches that allow more reliable and more efficient description of the disordered conformational ensembles of IDPs and their interactions, and 2) integration of multi-scale simulation and experiment to determine the molecular principles by which regulatory IDPs achieve robust and facile recognition of specific targets.

Specifically, advanced computational methods developed by this NSF project include new atomistic implicit solvent protein force fields, efficient topology-based coarse-grained modeling of IDP interactions, and new multi-scale sampling techniques that can benefit from both the efficiency of coarse-grained modeling and accuracy of atomistic force fields. These methods are also applicable to computer simulations of other biological systems beyond IDPs. A key lesson of IDP function obtained from our studies is that, although preformed structures frequently exist in unbound IDPs, they generally do not serve as initial binding sites to expedite recognition as previously assumed. Instead, regulatory IDPs tend to follow induced-folding like mechanisms. It has been further demonstrated that the somewhat surprising prevalence of induced folding in IDP recognition is likely due to the constraint of fast association required for cellular signaling and regulation. Combining simulation and experiment, we have uncovered a novel electrostatically accelerated encounter and folding mechanism that is likely prevalent in regulatory IDP recognitions. Together, efforts related to this project have led to 22 research articles in peer-reviewed journals, with several more in various stages of preparation. The results have also been presented numerous times at regional, national and international conferences as well as US and international institutions by the PI and members of his research team. All computational tools developed have been made available upon request as parts of broadly available general purpose computer simulation software packages including CHARMM, MMTSB, NAMD and GROMACS. All simulated IDP ensembles from our published works have been made available freely upon request.

The educational and outreach components of this project have focused on development of new courses, training of students and postdoctoral fellows, and organization and participation of outreach workshops targeting women and other minorities in science.  Specifically, 1) we have developed a new graduate course at Kansas State University (KSU) that proves basic and practical knowledge for properly performance of biomolecular modeling and analysis. The PI has also revamped an upper level undergraduate course to provide an up- to-date review of modern computational and experimental techniques for molecular biophysics. All new course materials are available for direct download through the PI’s lab website.  2) Five undergraduates (four females/minorities), six graduate students (two females) and four postdoctoral fellows (one female) have been involved in this project. Four of these graduate students have moved onto promising careers in academia, industry, or medical training.
